summary: Is Duty the Death of Love?
title: Is Duty the Death of Love?
body:
Or was love the death of duty? Or are duty and love one and the same? Does anything make sense anymore?!

I’m still asking myself this because how the heck does either “love is the death of duty” OR “duty is the death of love” work if we’re supposed to believe Jon is in love with Dany? For either to mean anything, we need two sides to the equation. Dany can’t be love and duty, and for the entirety of s8, Jon incessantly calls her his queen. It’s basically a third of his lines. So, it makes no sense to then try to pretend like his duty lies elsewhere. Jon tells her, “you are my queen, now and always,” and if he’s also in love with her, that means love and duty aligned. That ruins both quotes. There is only a conflict between the two if he has to choose between duty and love.

So, the show tries to imply it is duty to the Starks, his sisters, that makes Jon kill his love (Dany), but no one can look at Jon and Arya’s interaction and say, yep, in Jon’s head, Arya is duty. Arya is emphatically Jon’s family, and in the original conversation, family/love is on one side and duty/honor the other.

Maester Aemon: “Love is the death of duty. If the day should ever come when your Lord Father was forced to choose between honor on the one hand, and those he loves on the other, what would he do?”

and

“What is honor compared to a woman’s love? What is duty against the feel of a newborn son in your arms? Or a brother’s smile?”

So, where does Arya fall for Jon? Family/love? Or duty/honor? Killing Dany is dishonorable, it is undutiful, it is treasonous. For Jon, Dany is the duty/honor in this scenario.

In 8x06 Jon is the one who brings up “love is the death of duty.” That’s where his head goes when Tyrion is explaining why he needs to stop Dany. It is Tyrion who flips the expression: “Sometimes, duty is the death of love.”

Jon looks at him, and Tyrion continues, “You are the shield that guards the realms of men. You always try to do the right thing, no matter the cost. You’ve tried to protect people. Who’s the greatest threat to the people now? It’s a terrible thing I’m asking. It’s also the right thing. Do you think I’m the last man she’ll execute? Who is more dangerous than the rightful heir to the Iron Throne?”

Jon gets up, “That’s her decision. She is the queen.” He puts his hand on Tyrion’s shoulder, “I’m sorry, I can’t do this.”

Jon refuses the task of being the shield that guards the realms of men. Here he also decides he will not fight for himself. Duty to the realm, and self-preservation, will not move him. Why? Well, earlier in their conversation when Tyrion tried to get Jon to condemn what Dany did, he won’t, and Tyrion says, “You won’t say because you don’t want to betray her.” All of the “my queen” and “she’s our queen” and his reaction to hearing his parentage and calling it “treason,” none of it is ever couched in terms of love. It all comes back to Jon bending the knee to Dany. She is his queen. She is his duty. Serving her faithfully is how he maintains his honor. 

For the sake of duty/honor, he won’t criticize her, he refused to compare her decisions to his unfavorably, he refused to even entertain his own claim. He silenced his conscience and watched Varys burn, was prepared for Tyrion to die, was willing to die himself. 

Just like Ned in s1, Jon doesn’t fear for his own life. What moves Ned to lie and dishonor himself? Sansa. He calls himself a traitor to save her. What triggers Jon to act? The Stark girls. Arya reminds Jon in the previous scene Sansa won’t kneel and Tyrion mentions his sisters. As a last resort to get Jon to act, Tyrion tells Jon that Sansa doesn’t want Dany to be queen and that Jon has to “choose.” What did Aemon say?

“We’re all human. We all do our duty when there’s no cost to it. Honor comes easy then. Yet, sooner or later, in every man’s life, there comes a day when it is not easy. A day when he must choose.”

Ned and Jon both choose Sansa over their honor. The end of Jon’s arc is an echo of Ned’s. Ned lied to everyone, committed treason by protecting Jon. He chose family over his honor. He chose love of his sister over duty to his king. Jon chose love for his sister over duty to his queen. He too committed treason with bonus crimes/sins thrown in because he’s an overachiever.

Jon has struggled between his duty to the Night’s Watch and his desire to protect the Starks in the past. He chose duty before, so killing Dany is the long delayed/denied opportunity with much higher stakes and in a much more traumatizing scenario. He is torn between what he wants to do for love and the demands of duty, but this time, duty doesn’t stop him. For Ned and Jon both, love dictates these choices to abandon honor and forsake their duty.

That’s how parentage reveal ties into this. It certainly wasn’t there to get Jon on the throne, it wasn’t just there to make Dany crazy, it had to happen because Jon needed to know not just who he was, but who Ned was. Ned wasn’t the honorable man who always did his duty. Ned was a treasonous liar. Ned chose his family, he chose love. That’s the only way Jon isn’t going to spend the rest of his life hating himself. In time, he will be able to recognize that the man he has always wanted to be a worthy son of didn’t choose duty/honor either.

I don’t think this is an unfair interpretation of the finale because of how much they reference that conversation between Jon and Maester Aemon. They made it uncertain because they’re obsessed with leaving us in the dark, but the ideas are too imbedded for this to have been carelessness. When Tyrion talks to Jon later in 8x06, Jon is wrestling with the question, was killing Dany right. What was Jon’s answer to Aemon?

Aemon: “Love is the death of duty. If the day should ever come when your Lord Father was forced to choose between honor on the one hand, and those he loves on the other, what would he do?”

 Jon: “He would do whatever is right, no matter what.”

In season 8 Jon learned that Ned lied and committed treason, denying honor and duty, for love of his sister, for love of Jon. I think the audience knows that Ned was right. So, I don’t care what Tyrion thinks motivates Jon, and I’m rejecting the ambiguity that D&D prefer. In the end, Ned and Jon made the same choice. They chose family, they chose love. They both did what was right. And Jon will feel the same way in time.

This interpretation means that s8 did address Jon’s identity struggle in its own way. He chose the Starks, they chose him. Arya tells Jon he’s their family in 8x01, in 8x04 Jon tells Dany she is his queen but the Starks are his family, and then he chooses his family over her in 8x06. Arya threatens to kill Yara, and Sansa is willing to go to war to save Jon. Arya said Jon is her brother, and Sansa has said multiple times that Jon is a Stark to her. All of their actions in the finale prove that they fully accept Jon as one of them, and ultimately, he chooses to be one of them too. This is resolution for us and for Jon, even if the show refused to outright say it/show us.

And, not only does Jon’s choice tie his arc to Ned’s, uniting the first and last seasons to give us some feeling of closure, we can fold the whole series back on itself and see how the beginning and end align. This interpretation means the first and last episodes of the whole series are talking about the same idea which we can trace throughout each season for many characters, not just Jon.

In 8x02 we’re reminded of the quote from the very first episode when Sansa, Dany, and Jon are shown together as Bran says, “the things we do for love.” What do they each do for love this season? In the same episode Dany admits she came North for love of Jon. In the finale, Sansa comes South to save Jon. What does Jon do for love?

If Dany is Jon’s love, becoming complicit in mass murder and justifying it is what he does for love. That doesn’t resonate with the ideas presented in the show previously or with Jon’s character arc. However, if we keep duty/honor on the one side and family/love on the other for the finale, if Dany is duty/honor and the Starks/Sansa are family/love, what happens unites the beginning and end of the show via two shocking acts and our two significant quotes, “The things we do for love” and “Love is the death of duty.” In 1x01 Jaime attempts to kill Bran. In 8x06 Jon kills Dany. Jaime tried to kill for his sister, Jon does kill for Sansa.

The things we do for love.

Arya tells Jon he’s their family in 8x01, in 8x04 Jon tells Dany she is his queen but the Starks are his family, and then he chooses his family over her in 8x06. Arya threatens to kill Yara, and Sansa is willing to go to war to save Jon. Arya said Jon is her brother, and Sansa has said multiple times that Jon is a Stark to her. All of their actions in the finale prove that they fully accept Jon as one of them, and ultimately, he chooses to be one of them too. This is resolution for us and for Jon, even if the show refused to outright say it/show us.

And, not only does Jon’s choice tie his arc to Ned’s, uniting the first and last seasons to give us some feeling of closure, we can fold the whole series back on itself and see how the beginning and end align. This interpretation means the first and last episodes of the whole series are talking about the same idea which we can trace throughout each season for many characters, not just Jon.

In 8x02 we’re reminded of the quote from the very first episode when Sansa, Dany, and Jon are shown together as Bran says, “the things we do for love.” What do they each do for love this season? In the same episode Dany admits she came North for love of Jon. In the finale, Sansa comes South to save Jon. What does Jon do for love?

If Dany is Jon’s love, becoming complicit in mass murder and justifying it is what he does for love. That doesn’t resonate with the ideas presented in the show previously or with Jon’s character arc. However, if we keep duty/honor on the one side and family/love on the other for the finale, if Dany is duty/honor and the Starks/Sansa are family/love, what happens unites the beginning and end of the show via two shocking acts and our two significant quotes, “The things we do for love” and “Love is the death of duty.” In 1x01 Jaime attempts to kill Bran. In 8x06 Jon kills Dany. Jaime tried to kill for his sister, Jon does kill for Sansa.

The things we do for love.
trail.content:
Or was love the death of duty? Or are duty and love one and the same? Does anything make sense anymore?!

I’m still asking myself this because how the heck does either “love is the death of duty” OR “duty is the death of love” work if we’re supposed to believe Jon is in love with Dany? For either to mean anything, we need two sides to the equation. Dany can’t be love and duty, and for the entirety of s8, Jon incessantly calls her his queen. It’s basically a third of his lines. So, it makes no sense to then try to pretend like his duty lies elsewhere. Jon tells her, “you are my queen, now and always,” and if he’s also in love with her, that means love and duty aligned. That ruins both quotes. There is only a conflict between the two if he has to choose between duty and love.

So, the show tries to imply it is duty to the Starks, his sisters, that makes Jon kill his love (Dany), but no one can look at Jon and Arya’s interaction and say, yep, in Jon’s head, Arya is duty. Arya is emphatically Jon’s family, and in the original conversation, family/love is on one side and duty/honor the other.

Maester Aemon: “Love is the death of duty. If the day should ever come when your Lord Father was forced to choose between honor on the one hand, and those he loves on the other, what would he do?”

and

“What is honor compared to a woman’s love? What is duty against the feel of a newborn son in your arms? Or a brother’s smile?”

So, where does Arya fall for Jon? Family/love? Or duty/honor? Killing Dany is dishonorable, it is undutiful, it is treasonous. For Jon, Dany is the duty/honor in this scenario.

In 8x06 Jon is the one who brings up “love is the death of duty.” That’s where his head goes when Tyrion is explaining why he needs to stop Dany. It is Tyrion who flips the expression: “Sometimes, duty is the death of love.”

Jon looks at him, and Tyrion continues, “You are the shield that guards the realms of men. You always try to do the right thing, no matter the cost. You’ve tried to protect people. Who’s the greatest threat to the people now? It’s a terrible thing I’m asking. It’s also the right thing. Do you think I’m the last man she’ll execute? Who is more dangerous than the rightful heir to the Iron Throne?”

Jon gets up, “That’s her decision. She is the queen.” He puts his hand on Tyrion’s shoulder, “I’m sorry, I can’t do this.”

Jon refuses the task of being the shield that guards the realms of men. Here he also decides he will not fight for himself. Duty to the realm, and self-preservation, will not move him. Why? Well, earlier in their conversation when Tyrion tried to get Jon to condemn what Dany did, he won’t, and Tyrion says, “You won’t say because you don’t want to betray her.” All of the “my queen” and “she’s our queen” and his reaction to hearing his parentage and calling it “treason,” none of it is ever couched in terms of love. It all comes back to Jon bending the knee to Dany. She is his queen. She is his duty. Serving her faithfully is how he maintains his honor. 

For the sake of duty/honor, he won’t criticize her, he refused to compare her decisions to his unfavorably, he refused to even entertain his own claim. He silenced his conscience and watched Varys burn, was prepared for Tyrion to die, was willing to die himself. 

Just like Ned in s1, Jon doesn’t fear for his own life. What moves Ned to lie and dishonor himself? Sansa. He calls himself a traitor to save her. What triggers Jon to act? The Stark girls. Arya reminds Jon in the previous scene Sansa won’t kneel and Tyrion mentions his sisters. As a last resort to get Jon to act, Tyrion tells Jon that Sansa doesn’t want Dany to be queen and that Jon has to “choose.” What did Aemon say?

“We’re all human. We all do our duty when there’s no cost to it. Honor comes easy then. Yet, sooner or later, in every man’s life, there comes a day when it is not easy. A day when he must choose.”

Ned and Jon both choose Sansa over their honor. The end of Jon’s arc is an echo of Ned’s. Ned lied to everyone, committed treason by protecting Jon. He chose family over his honor. He chose love of his sister over duty to his king. Jon chose love for his sister over duty to his queen. He too committed treason with bonus crimes/sins thrown in because he’s an overachiever.

Jon has struggled between his duty to the Night’s Watch and his desire to protect the Starks in the past. He chose duty before, so killing Dany is the long delayed/denied opportunity with much higher stakes and in a much more traumatizing scenario. He is torn between what he wants to do for love and the demands of duty, but this time, duty doesn’t stop him. For Ned and Jon both, love dictates these choices to abandon honor and forsake their duty.

That’s how parentage reveal ties into this. It certainly wasn’t there to get Jon on the throne, it wasn’t just there to make Dany crazy, it had to happen because Jon needed to know not just who he was, but who Ned was. Ned wasn’t the honorable man who always did his duty. Ned was a treasonous liar. Ned chose his family, he chose love. That’s the only way Jon isn’t going to spend the rest of his life hating himself. In time, he will be able to recognize that the man he has always wanted to be a worthy son of didn’t choose duty/honor either.

I don’t think this is an unfair interpretation of the finale because of how much they reference that conversation between Jon and Maester Aemon. They made it uncertain because they’re obsessed with leaving us in the dark, but the ideas are too imbedded for this to have been carelessness. When Tyrion talks to Jon later in 8x06, Jon is wrestling with the question, was killing Dany right. What was Jon’s answer to Aemon?

Aemon: “Love is the death of duty. If the day should ever come when your Lord Father was forced to choose between honor on the one hand, and those he loves on the other, what would he do?”

 Jon: “He would do whatever is right, no matter what.”

In season 8 Jon learned that Ned lied and committed treason, denying honor and duty, for love of his sister, for love of Jon. I think the audience knows that Ned was right. So, I don’t care what Tyrion thinks motivates Jon, and I’m rejecting the ambiguity that D&D prefer. In the end, Ned and Jon made the same choice. They chose family, they chose love. They both did what was right. And Jon will feel the same way in time.

This interpretation means that s8 did address Jon’s identity struggle in its own way. He chose the Starks, they chose him. Arya tells Jon he’s their family in 8x01, in 8x04 Jon tells Dany she is his queen but the Starks are his family, and then he chooses his family over her in 8x06. Arya threatens to kill Yara, and Sansa is willing to go to war to save Jon. Arya said Jon is her brother, and Sansa has said multiple times that Jon is a Stark to her. All of their actions in the finale prove that they fully accept Jon as one of them, and ultimately, he chooses to be one of them too. This is resolution for us and for Jon, even if the show refused to outright say it/show us.

And, not only does Jon’s choice tie his arc to Ned’s, uniting the first and last seasons to give us some feeling of closure, we can fold the whole series back on itself and see how the beginning and end align. This interpretation means the first and last episodes of the whole series are talking about the same idea which we can trace throughout each season for many characters, not just Jon.

In 8x02 we’re reminded of the quote from the very first episode when Sansa, Dany, and Jon are shown together as Bran says, “the things we do for love.” What do they each do for love this season? In the same episode Dany admits she came North for love of Jon. In the finale, Sansa comes South to save Jon. What does Jon do for love?

If Dany is Jon’s love, becoming complicit in mass murder and justifying it is what he does for love. That doesn’t resonate with the ideas presented in the show previously or with Jon’s character arc. However, if we keep duty/honor on the one side and family/love on the other for the finale, if Dany is duty/honor and the Starks/Sansa are family/love, what happens unites the beginning and end of the show via two shocking acts and our two significant quotes, “The things we do for love” and “Love is the death of duty.” In 1x01 Jaime attempts to kill Bran. In 8x06 Jon kills Dany. Jaime tried to kill for his sister, Jon does kill for Sansa.

The things we do for love.
trail.content_abstract:
Or was love the death of duty? Or are duty and love one and the same? Does anything make sense anymore?!

I’m still asking myself this because how the heck does either “love is the death of duty” OR “duty is the death of love” work if we’re supposed to believe Jon is in love with Dany? For either to mean anything, we need two sides to the equation. Dany can’t be love and duty, and for the entirety of s8, Jon incessantly calls her his queen. It’s basically a third of his lines. So, the show tries to imply it is duty to the Starks, his sisters, that makes Jon kill his love (Dany), but no one can look at Jon and Arya’s interaction and say, yep, in Jon’s head, Arya is duty. Arya is emphatically Jon’s family, and in the original conversation, family/love is on one side and duty/honor the other.

summary: There was something else, in addition to the events, that made them all the more interesting to Sansa. It was something neither...
text: There was something else, in addition to the events, that made them all the more interesting to Sansa. It was something neither she nor her parents had anticipated, but it gave the tournament an entirely different flavor than before. It should have been no surprise that the Westermen would go into their games, just as they would into war, with their traditional kilts in the colors of their clan. What none of the Northerners had prepared themselves for, was for what that meant while they competed in such close quarters during the individual events. Westermen wore not a stitch of clothing under their kilts, nothing to hide what the gods had graced them with from the view of others.
source:
Midsummer Eve’s Bounty, Unpublished Chapter 6: The Westerland Games

Read the story here: https://archiveofourown.org/works/18197315/chapters/43045367

We are working hard to get this chapter up!

it's soulmates AND roommates AND fake dating!!!!
not to mention a slowburn enemies to friends to lovers
summary: Home. In a world that’s black and white until you meet your soulmate, Theon and Sansa have both seen colors for as long as they...
caption:
Home.

In a world that’s black and white until you meet your soulmate, Theon and Sansa have both seen colors for as long as they can remember. But neither knows who their soulmate is.

Now Theon needs a fake soulmate and Sansa needs a real roommate, so together they agree to put aside their differences - only to discover they’re not very different at all.

Now Theon needs a fake soulmate and Sansa needs a real roommate, so together they agree to put aside their differences - only to discover they’re not very different at all.

summary: Reason #25: Sansa is Jon’s (T)REASON - The last betrayal Dany knew was Jon’s betrayal “for love” a.k.a. Sansa Stark:
title: Reason #25: Sansa is Jon’s (T)REASON - The last betrayal Dany knew was Jon’s betrayal “for love” a.k.a. Sansa Stark:
body:
Look, I know they did not give us canon Jonsa. I know they made it look as if Jon was too dumb with love of Dany to do the right thing. And yes, the writing was bad and turned Jon into a muppet…

BUT fact is and fact remains that in the end, everything that happened in the last episode, the one big choice that Jon made all came back to Sansa…

Jon’s constant repetition that Dany was “his queen” and that even the idea that he could dethrone her was “TREASON” (he said it to Sam, he said it to his siblings, he said it to Varys)  - frustrating as it is, is also a build up to the pivotal moment of Jon’s committing the ultimate treason: regicide. 

Jon’s stupidity, his blind faith in Dany and refusal to see how far she’d gone over to the dark side, it does make Jon look idiotically naive and blind with lust love for her, i.e. Robb 2.0. But what shines through is always the absent spectre of Sansa on his mind: When Dany screams that they will go for Winterfell next, when Arya is pushing the thought to the front of his mind: “Try telling Sansa.” and finally Tyrion, solidifying Jon’s reason: “Why do you think Sansa told me?”

And that’s the crucial moment. That’s where Brainless!Jon has an enlightened moment and it is fear for Sansa that brings out his last two braincells. 

Did he listen to Tyrion at all before he brought up Sansa? Nope. 

Was Jon prepared to do it for any other reason but this? Didn’t seem so. 

Jon was in denial before Tyrion dropped the one name that triggers Jon like no other: 

So perhaps there was a method to Jon’s madness whenever he went Kill Bill sirens at Sansa’s name. That running gag had to lead *somewhere*

Jon not seeing the necessity of stopping Dany after what she had done and only seeing it when someone close to his heart is in danger makes Jon dumb af, yes, but it also serves to confirm one major theory: 

Jon *was* the last of Dany’s three treasons. 

Jon betrayed and killed Dany for LOVE of Sansa - which means he was actually her “betrayal for love”

Some might argue that it was rather the “betrayal for blood” because the Starks are his family…

But there was already one other betrayal “for blood” a little earlier on that someone committed for someone closer related: 

Tyrion betrayed Dany for Jaime, his brother (and to some degree even for Cersei and their unborn child)

Tyrion *was* her betrayal “for blood” and Dany even got to condemn him for it. 

We’d speculated before how the “betrayal for love” could also be something to do with Missandei and Greyworm, but nope…

The “betrayal for love” remained unfulfilled until the moment Jon pulled that knife and killed “his queen” because she was a threat to someone Jon loved far more than Dany. 

Sansa was the (t)reason for Jon. 

Say what you want about Jonsa happening or not happening…

This is canon. Jon did betray Dany. And it was the last betrayal she would know: “once for love” 

So yeah, they had no time for a proper Jonsa endgame and chose not to pull it off, but even the bad writing had some gems in it and the outcome is that Jon saved and protected Sansa from Dany’s wrath because he loved her (however which way you want to interpret it). 

There was a lot of talk about “choices” and who gets to “choose” whom - both Jon and Dany saying that Sansa does not “get to choose” - but in the end, it is Jon who makes a fateful choice: 

Jon chooses Sansa over Dany. 

And they both survived and returned North and the ending was deliberately left wide open to every possibility of them seeing each other again at some point…

Jonsa is not canon. 

But it is alive and well, somewhere up North.

summary: If your still making icons, can you please make some season 1 Sansa icons? Thanks in advance <3

sure!

summary: As much as I loathe what they did to Arya I also don’t like what they did to Sansa. They made Sansa Elizabeth I. As if her being...
body:
As much as I loathe what they did to Arya I also don’t like what they did to Sansa. They made Sansa Elizabeth I. As if her being a victim of rape ruined her and that she like Arya is not allowed to overcome her trauma and be loved.

They may not have explicitly stated it but the implications are there. House Stark is going to die within their lifetimes. Bran cannot have children, Arya’s apparently fucked off to West of Westros and may or may not come back and Sansa’s just going to be married to the concept of the North.

Granted, marriage and children are not the end all and be all but connetion to family, having support and love? Those are so important and Sansa wanted to have romance and children. Why shouldn’t she? 

I hate the ending so much because it not only murdered Daenerys (a barren woman), but it isolated Sansa and Arya denying them their familial connections, their friends, and love in their lives whereas Bran has several important and named character in his ending (Tyrion, Samwell, Davos, Brienne, Pod and even Bronn) and Jon gets to leave to be at peace with Tormond and Ghost with the Freefolk in the North. 

I’m still so mad.

Granted, marriage and children are not the end all and be all but connetion to family, having support and love? Those are so important and Sansa wanted to have romance and children. Why shouldn’t she? 

I hate the ending so much because it not only murdered Daenerys (a barren woman), but it isolated Sansa and Arya denying them their familial connections, their friends, and love in their lives whereas Bran has several important and named character in his ending (Tyrion, Samwell, Davos, Brienne, Pod and even Bronn) and Jon gets to leave to be at peace with Tormond and Ghost with the Freefolk in the North.

They may not have explicitly stated it but the implications are there. House Stark is going to die within their lifetimes. Bran cannot have children, Arya’s apparently fucked off to West of Westros and may or may not come back and Sansa’s just going to be married to the concept of the North.

Granted, marriage and children are not the end all and be all but connetion to family, having support and love? Those are so important and Sansa wanted to have romance and children. Why shouldn’t she? 

I hate the ending so much because it not only murdered Daenerys (a barren woman), but it isolated Sansa and Arya denying them their familial connections, their friends, and love in their lives whereas Bran has several important and named character in his ending (Tyrion, Samwell, Davos, Brienne, Pod and even Bronn) and Jon gets to leave to be at peace with Tormond and Ghost with the Freefolk in the North.
